Content: What is the relative impact of rectal antiseptic preparation with povidone-iodine compared with targeted antibiotic prophylaxis in reducing post-biopsy sepsis following transrectal procedures, and could a combined strategy enhance infection control without contributing to antimicrobial resistance?
Saline as Effective as Antiseptics for Post-Biopsy Infection Prevention
Assessment: How consistent/coherent is the cluster?

Content: A study found that mechanical cleaning of rectal mucosa with saline was as effective as antiseptic solutions in reducing general complications, fever, acute prostatitis, and sepsis following TRUS-PB. This suggests saline, a cost-effective, side-effect-free, and easy-to-apply alternative, can be a viable infection prevention method, especially for patients with antiseptic allergies, prompting reconsideration of antiseptic solution necessity, despite study limitations including data gaps and absent rectal microorganism swab culture. (Confidence: 80.0%)
Assessment: How relevant ist the nugget to the query?

Content: The study aimed to investigate whether reduced infection rates were due to antiseptic solutions or the mechanical effect of rectal irrigation. Patients were randomized into three equal groups based on their rectal irrigation strategy, with the control group receiving rectal irrigation with physiological saline solution and antibiotic prophylaxis. (Confidence: 80.0%)
Assessment: How relevant ist the nugget to the query?

Content: Mechanical cleaning methods with saline are cheap, easy to apply, and have no side effects, protecting against possible infections with similar efficacy to other antiseptic solutions. This challenges the prevailing belief that antiseptic solutions are indispensable for infection prevention. (Confidence: 80.0%)
Assessment: How relevant ist the nugget to the query?

Content: This randomized clinical trial, reported using the CONSORT checklist, involved flushing the rectal mucosa with 50 ml each of 10% povidone-iodine, 4% chlorhexidine, and saline via a pine-tipped syringe, followed by a two-minute wait for bactericidal effect; patients did not receive enema bowel preparation, and their cleansing methods were unknown to the doctor. Many studies indicate that these cheap, effective antiseptic solutions used for rectal mucosa cleaning positively contribute to infection control. (Confidence: 80.0%)
Assessment: How relevant ist the nugget to the query?

Content: Sepsis is one of the most dreaded complications following prostate biopsy, and rectal cleansing appeared to be the most effective strategy to reduce this risk. While cleansing agents varied, most studies used povidone-iodine; for example, in one analysis of 11 studies, nine reported on povidone-iodine, one on chlorhexidine, and one on an antimicrobial solution. (Confidence: 100.0%)
Assessment: How relevant ist the nugget to the query?

Content: Comparing Biopsy Methods: Infection, Antibiotics, and Stewardship
Assessment: How consistent/coherent is the cluster?

Content: TRUS biopsy was typically performed with local anaesthetic infiltration and pre- and post-procedure antibiotics as the standard-of-care at recruitment centers, but concerns about its infectious complications are now leading to the increasing popularity of local anaesthetic trans-perineal (LATP) biopsy. (Confidence: 100.0%)
Assessment: How relevant ist the nugget to the query?

Content: The TRANSLATE trial compared transrectal ultrasound (TRUS) biopsies, for which all participants received antibiotics, with local anaesthetic transperineal (LATP) biopsies, performed with chlorhexidine-based skin preparation and largely without antibiotics (89% of cases). The LATP approach resulted in fewer post-biopsy infections requiring hospitalisation (2 [<1%] vs 9 [2%] within 35 days) and fewer overall infectious complications (6 [1%] vs 13 [2%] over 4 months) compared to TRUS, demonstrating that most LATP biopsies can be safely performed without antibiotics, which is important for antibiotic stewardship. (Confidence: 100.0%)
Assessment: How relevant ist the nugget to the query?

Content: Routine surgical disinfection of the perineal skin is recommended before performing a transperineal biopsy. For antibiotic prophylaxis in transrectal biopsy, from an antimicrobial stewardship perspective, recommended options include targeted prophylaxis based on rectal swab or stool culture, or augmented prophylaxis using two or more different classes of antibiotics. (Confidence: 100.0%)
Assessment: How relevant ist the nugget to the query?

Content: Transrectal biopsy (TRBx) is inherently associated with a risk of infectious complications, including sepsis, and a higher incidence of infection than transperineal biopsy (TPBx). While targeted antibiotic prophylaxis (based on rectal cultures) is administered in TRBx, the provided information does not detail or compare specific prophylactic methods like povidone-iodine or targeted antibiotics, their relative impact, or a combined strategy. (Confidence: 100.0%)
Assessment: How relevant ist the nugget to the query?

Content: Prostate Biopsy Prophylaxis: FQ Ban, Resistance, and Targeted Strategies
Assessment: How consistent/coherent is the cluster?

Content: The European Commission has implemented stringent regulatory conditions, suspending the indication for fluoroquinquinolones in peri-operative antibiotic prophylaxis for prostate biopsy (EMEA/H/A-31/1452), thus they should not be used. While targeted prophylaxis based on rectal swab/stool culture is plausible and augmented prophylaxis without fluoroquinolones is a possibility, no randomized controlled trials (RCTs) are available for non-fluoroquinolone options nor is a standard combination established, with urologists advised to check local guidance for fosfomycin trometamol. (Confidence: 100.0%)
Assessment: How relevant ist the nugget to the query?

Content: Antimicrobial prophylaxis with TAZ/PIPC prevented prostatitis in positive-culture patients, averting potentially life-threatening sepsis and costly hospitalization. Culture-based, targeted prevention consequently reduces hospitalizations from antibiotic-resistant pathogens and lowers long-term healthcare costs, a crucial benefit given the European Commission's ban on fluoroquinolones (FQs) for urological perioperative prophylaxis due to a negative benefit-risk balance and rising drug resistance. (Confidence: 80.0%)
Assessment: How relevant ist the nugget to the query?

Content: Screening with selective media before TRPB in low infectious risk patients provides additive value in preventing post-biopsy prostatitis by enabling targeted antimicrobial prophylaxis against the rising trend of FQ-resistant and ESBL-producing E. coli, for which TAZ/PIPC is recommended upon detection. This method accurately detects targeted resistant strains, such as LVFX-resistant bacteria identified in 28.6% of patients, with LVFX-insusceptible media demonstrating 98.1% sensitivity and 94.7% specificity. (Confidence: 80.0%)
Assessment: How relevant ist the nugget to the query?

Content: A multicenter, randomized, controlled clinical trial investigates selective culture media to identify FQ-resistant or ESBL-producing E. coli for appropriate prophylactic antimicrobial administration to prevent acute prostatitis before TRPB. Among 4 patients with acute prostatitis, 3 from the Negative-culture group who received oral LVFX before TRPB had urine cultures at onset (n=3) showing two LVFX-insusceptible, ESBL-nonproducing E. coli and one negative result; their median qSOFA was 0 (0-1), WBC 8250 /µL (4070-12,500), and CRP 0.9 mg/dL (0.5-1.4). (Confidence: 80.0%)
Assessment: How relevant ist the nugget to the query?

Content: Transrectal Prostate Biopsy: Infection Prevention Strategies
Assessment: How consistent/coherent is the cluster?

Content: Antimicrobial prophylaxis is recommended for transrectal prostate biopsy, encompassing targeted prophylaxis based on rectal swab or stool culture, augmented prophylaxis using two or more different antibiotic classes, or alternative antibiotics such as fosfomycin trometamol, cephalosporins (e.g., ceftriaxone, cefixime), and aminoglycosides (e.g., gentamicin, amikacin) with their specific regimens. (Confidence: 80.0%)
Assessment: How relevant ist the nugget to the query?

Content: A meta-analysis of 15 studies with 12,320 patients found infectious complications after transrectal prostate biopsy (TRPB) were 3.4% with empirical antimicrobial prophylaxis but only 0.8% with targeted prophylaxis based on pre-biopsy rectal culture for resistant pathogens. A separate trial, focused on preventing acute post-biopsy prostatitis, demonstrated the effectiveness of rectal culture using selective media before TRPB to confirm resistant bacteria and guide antimicrobial selection, observing post-biopsy prostatitis in 4 (1.1%) patients who received either culture-based or no culture-based LVFX prophylaxis. (Confidence: 80.0%)
Assessment: How relevant ist the nugget to the query?

Content: An ethically approved study (Izmir Tepecik Training and Research Hospital, March 2022, decision 2022/03-05) conducted from April 2022 to June 2023 included patients undergoing transrectal prostate biopsy for elevated PSA, abnormal DRE, PIRADS ≥3 on mpMRI, or active surveillance. All patients received standard antibiotic prophylaxis (2g ceftriaxone IV pre-biopsy, followed by 2g cefixime PO daily for 2 days, or 1g amikacin daily for 3 days if ceftriaxone was contraindicated) and were randomized into three equal groups based on their rectal irrigation strategy. (Confidence: 80.0%)
Assessment: How relevant ist the nugget to the query?

Content: Rectal cleansing prior to transrectal prostate biopsy significantly reduces bacterial introduction and infectious complications, emerging as potentially the most effective strategy. Its efficacy may surpass rectal culture-based antibiotic prophylaxis and be comparable to or better than transperineal biopsy, with both rectal cleansing and culture-based prophylaxis being guideline-supported for transrectal procedures, though further comparative trials are needed. (Confidence: 100.0%)
Assessment: How relevant ist the nugget to the query?

Content: Povidone-Iodine Rectal Disinfection: Usage, Guidelines, and Complications
Assessment: How consistent/coherent is the cluster?

Content: Rectal povidone-iodine disinfection was applied. (Confidence: 100.0%)
Assessment: How relevant ist the nugget to the query?

Content: Although EAU guidelines recommend povidone-iodine rectal preparation prior to TRUS-PB, some included studies did not perform it, and others did not describe whether it was performed. Specifically, only one RCT (Sadahira et al. [7]) described performing this disinfection, while two RCTs [8,9] reported not performing it, and information on disinfection was not provided in the remaining studies. (Confidence: 80.0%)
Assessment: How relevant ist the nugget to the query?

Content: While one study found no statistically significant difference in complications among povidone-iodine (2 patients), chlorhexidine (5 patients), and saline (5 patients) groups (p=0.780), prospective studies have shown that rectal cleaning with povidone-iodine statistically significantly reduces bacteremia and led to fewer signs and symptoms of infection; however, a reported 42% reduction in infectious complications was not statistically significant in one such study. (Confidence: 80.0%)
Assessment: How relevant ist the nugget to the query?

Content: Prostate Biopsy: Tailored Antibiotics & Transperineal Approach
Assessment: How consistent/coherent is the cluster?

Content: For transrectal prostate biopsy, there is moderate evidence from multiple studies and four meta-analyses that a combined strategy of targeted antibiotic prophylaxis (t-PAP), guided by pre-procedure rectal swab results, and povidone-iodine rectal disinfection effectively reduces postoperative infectious complications. Four of these meta-analyses specifically indicate t-PAP reduces infection risk by 40-80% compared to empirical prophylaxis, showing complication rates for t-PAP as low as 0.6-0.8% versus 3.1-3.4% for empirical PAP. (Confidence: 100.0%)
Assessment: How relevant ist the nugget to the query?

Content: Transperineal (TP-Tbx) prostate biopsies can safely omit prophylactic antibiotics without increasing infection risk, aligning with antibiotic stewardship and reducing potential resistance, while transrectal (TR-Tbx) biopsies necessitate tailored antibiotic prophylaxis, incurring significant costs and logistical challenges, and showing a directional favor towards TP for reducing infections and sepsis. (Confidence: 100.0%)
Assessment: How relevant ist the nugget to the query?

Content: Prostate biopsy, the primary method for diagnosing prostate cancer, can be performed via transrectal (TR) or transperineal (TP) approaches. Current studies suggest the TP approach does not require prophylactic antibiotic treatment (PAP) and should be favored over the TR approach, which always necessitates PAP, especially as global prostate cancer incidence and biopsy frequency are projected to double by 2040, making every instance of forgoing PAP a success. (Confidence: 100.0%)
Assessment: How relevant ist the nugget to the query?

Content: Targeted Prophylaxis: Quinolone Resistance Challenges Effectiveness

Content: TPAs based on rectal swab culture significantly reduce the incidence of fUTI, however, the influence of quinolone-resistant bacteria on their effectiveness in reducing fUTI remains unclear. (Confidence: 80.0%)

Content: Quinolones are frequently used for prophylaxis and evaluated in studies; however, the emergence of quinolone resistance has increased the risk of infection. This makes the use of third-generation cephalosporins instead of quinolones a possible limitation for our study. (Confidence: 80.0%)
Assessment: How relevant ist the nugget to the query?

Content: Rectal culture-based antibiotic prophylaxis significantly lowers the risk of infectious complications compared to empirical antibiotics, which are the least effective measure due to rising antimicrobial resistance, with fluoro-quinolone resistance reported as high as 45%. (Confidence: 100.0%)

Content: Prostate Biopsy Routes, Antibiotic Prophylaxis, and Infection Risk
Assessment: How consistent/coherent is the cluster?

Content: For transrectal biopsies, weak recommendations suggest using either targeted antibiotic prophylaxis based on rectal swab or stool culture, or augmented prophylaxis with two or more different antibiotic classes. However, the transperineal biopsy route is preferred over transrectal due to factors including antibiotic stewardship, feasibility under local anesthesia, and comparable cancer detection rates, despite potential logistical challenges. (Confidence: 100.0%)
Assessment: How relevant ist the nugget to the query?

Content: The PREVENT randomized trial [12] compared transperineal (TP) biopsy without antibiotic prophylaxis to transrectal (TR) biopsy with targeted prophylaxis. For the TR approach, a rectal swab was performed prior to biopsy to screen for fluoroquinolone-resistant organisms, with targeted antibiotics administered based on culture and sensitivity results: fluoroquinolone prophylaxis if no resistance was detected, or an alternative antibiotic based on sensitivities for allergic patients or those with resistant strains. (Confidence: 100.0%)
Assessment: How relevant ist the nugget to the query?

Content: A randomized-controlled study by Hu et al. involving 658 patients compared infectious complications following transperineal biopsy (TPB) without prophylactic antibiotic prophylaxis (PAP) versus transrectal biopsy (TRB) with PAP, finding no higher infection rates for TPB. In this study, a rectal culture to screen for fluoroquinolone-resistant organisms was obtained prior to transrectal biopsy in all patients, and targeted PAP was administered. (Confidence: 100.0%)
Assessment: How relevant ist the nugget to the query?

Content: Prostate Biopsy Antibiotics: Changing Strategies and Resistance Concerns.
Assessment: How consistent/coherent is the cluster?

Content: Antibiotic prophylaxis is mandatory before transrectal prostate biopsy (TRPB) to prevent infectious complications, with fluoroquinolones (FQs) no longer accepted in the EU and current EAU guidelines recommending an algorithm where targeted prophylaxis (based on rectal swab results) is the first option but often unfeasible, still requiring non-quinolone antibiotics. The overall sepsis rate observed was 0.98%, with no significant difference between groups (0% vs. 1.96%, P = 0.50), including urosepsis confirmed once (0.98%) in Arm B. (Confidence: 100.0%)
Assessment: How relevant ist the nugget to the query?

Content: The comparison of urinary tract infection and sepsis rates following transperineal prostate biopsies suggests antibiotic prophylaxis may not be necessary for these procedures. This is relevant as antibiotic use, particularly unnecessary prophylactic administration, is associated with and exacerbates antibiotic resistance, a global health challenge affecting the entire medical system beyond urology, thereby supporting efforts to reduce antibiotic prescriptions to curb microbial resistance. (Confidence: 100.0%)
Assessment: How relevant ist the nugget to the query?

Content: Targeted prophylactic antibiotics (TPAs) based on rectal swab culture significantly reduced the incidence of febrile urinary tract infection (fUTI) after transrectal ultrasound-guided prostate biopsy (TRUS-PB) from 5.2% to 2.7% (a 46% reduction; RR: 0.54, 95% CI: 0.36-0.81, p = 0.003; NNT: 40) compared with empiric prophylactic antibiotics. However, there was no statistically significant difference in sepsis incidence (1.3% vs 1.8%, RR: 0.74, 95% CI: 0.31-1.75, p = 0.4) between the two approaches. (Confidence: 80.0%)
Assessment: How relevant ist the nugget to the query?

Content: Prostate Biopsy: Prophylaxis, Complications, and Antimicrobial Stewardship
Assessment: How consistent/coherent is the cluster?

Content: In Germany, there is currently no gold standard for antibiotic choice in prophylaxis for transrectal prostate biopsy; however, rectal disinfection with povidone-iodine immediately before the biopsy is recommended regardless of the antibiotic chosen. Targeted antibiotic prophylaxis (t-PAP) further limits broad-spectrum antibiotic use by over 80%, making it favorable for antibiotic stewardship [Cornford 2024]. (Confidence: 100.0%)
Assessment: How relevant ist the nugget to the query?

Content: For transrectal prostate biopsies (TRPBs), antibiotic prophylaxis and povidone-iodine rectal preparation are recommended. This is crucial as infectious complications have increased due to FQ-resistant bacteria; therefore, single-dose FMT prophylaxis is also recommended for TRPBs to prevent overuse and any negative ecological impact. (Confidence: 100.0%)
Assessment: How relevant ist the nugget to the query?

Content: Post-biopsy complications following transrectal ultrasound-guided prostate biopsy (TRUS PB) included fever, acute prostatitis, acute urinary retention, gross hematuria, sepsis, and septic shock, and were evaluated by admissions to emergency departments or outpatient clinics within 15 days; acute prostatitis, sepsis, or septic shock specifically led to hospitalization. The overall complication rate was 4%, with no statistically significant difference detected between povidone-iodine (2 patients), chlorhexidine (5 patients), and saline (5 patients) groups (p=0.780). (Confidence: 80.0%)
Assessment: How relevant ist the nugget to the query?

Content: Fluoroquinolone Resistance: New Prophylaxis Strategies and Alternatives
Assessment: How consistent/coherent is the cluster?

Content: Updated meta-analyses show that targeted therapy (antibiotic guidance based on rectal swab microbiology) for fluoroquinolone resistance [RR 0.52 (0.39-0.69) from nine RCTs, 3,096 patients] and augmented prophylaxis (two or more antibiotic classes) [RR 0.44 (0.32-0.59) from ten RCTs, 2,787 patients] significantly reduce infectious complications. Additionally, a meta-analysis of two RCTs indicates cephalosporins or aminoglycosides offer comparable infectious complications as individual agents in countries where fluoroquinolone use is suspended. (Confidence: 100.0%)
Assessment: How relevant ist the nugget to the query?

Content: Fluoroquinolones have traditionally been used for antibiotic prophylaxis, but their overuse and misuse have led to increased resistance; consequently, augmented prophylaxis without fluoroquinolones is a possibility, though no standard combination has been established to date. (Confidence: 100.0%)
Assessment: How relevant ist the nugget to the query?

Content: Fluoroquinolones, traditionally used for antibiotic prophylaxis in transrectal biopsies, are now challenged by increased resistance and stringent European regulations leading to their suspension for peri-operative use, prompting a shift to alternatives like cephalosporins or aminoglycosides where restricted. Other strategies include augmented prophylaxis (lacking standard combinations) and targeted prophylaxis based on rectal culture (without non-fluoroquinolone RCTs), while fosfomycin trometamol, despite some superiority data, has been withdrawn in Germany due to insufficient pharmacokinetic data, necessitating local guidance checks. (Confidence: 100.0%)
Assessment: How relevant ist the nugget to the query?

Content: An updated meta-analysis of eleven RCTs involving 2,237 men showed that using rectal povidone-iodine preparation before transrectal prostate biopsy, in addition to antimicrobial prophylaxis, significantly lowered the rate of infectious complications [RR (95% CIs) 0.47 (0.36 to 0.61)]. (Confidence: 100.0%)
Assessment: How relevant ist the nugget to the query?

Content: As a uniform procedure, povidone-iodine rectal disinfection was performed before transrectal prostate biopsy (TRPB). (Confidence: 80.0%)

Content: An updated meta-analysis of eleven RCTs involving 2,237 men demonstrated that rectal povidone-iodine preparation before transrectal biopsy, when used with antimicrobial prophylaxis, significantly reduced infectious complications (RR: 0.47; 95% CI [0.36–0.61]), leading to a strong recommendation for its use prior to transrectal prostate biopsy. Additionally, single RCTs reported an advantage for preparation before biopsy compared to after. (Confidence: 100.0%)

Content: Antibiotic Resistance: Infection Risk and Prophylaxis Strategies
Assessment: How consistent/coherent is the cluster?

Content: None of the TRANSLATE recruitment centres used enhanced or rectal culture-guided prophylaxis, as these are not routinely used in the UK, nor did the UK study incorporate regular targeted antibiotic prophylaxis with pre-procedure rectal swabs, a practice that might be undertaken in some other countries. The necessary exclusion of participants at higher risk of infection for successful randomisation likely reduced the infection event rate in both groups of this study. (Confidence: 100.0%)

Content: Risk patients with an increased infection or resistance rate, for whom a rectal swab for targeted antibiotic prophylaxis is recommended, are characterized by factors such as a history of (recurrent) prostatitis/urinary tract infection, diabetes mellitus with increased infection risk, immunosuppression, antibiotic intake up to one year prior, or travel to countries with high antibiotic resistance. (Confidence: 80.0%)
Assessment: How relevant ist the nugget to the query?

Content: Increasing antibiotic resistance and infection rates have prompted physicians to seek new solutions, as infective complications deter patients from necessary repeat biopsies. While one study found no difference between groups with identical antibiotic regimens, another demonstrated fewer infection signs and symptoms in the RCPI group. (Confidence: 80.0%)

Content: TRUS-PB Sepsis Prophylaxis: Efficacy Inconclusive, More Research Needed
Assessment: How consistent/coherent is the cluster?

Content: The available evidence was insufficient to detect a statistically significant difference in sepsis risk (RR: 0.74, 95% CI: 0.31-1.75, p = 0.5) between the two approaches, primarily because the low incidence rate of sepsis after TRUS-PB limited statistical power. Significant heterogeneity among included studies, potentially due to varying or absent sepsis definitions introducing classification bias, also reduced precision and indicates a need for further research. (Confidence: 80.0%)
Assessment: How relevant ist the nugget to the query?

Content: No significant difference was found in the incidence rate of sepsis after TRUS-PB between patients receiving targeted prophylactic antibiotics based on rectal swab culture and those receiving empiric prophylactic antibiotics; therefore, larger studies are needed to conclusively determine their efficacy in reducing sepsis. (Confidence: 80.0%)
Assessment: How relevant ist the nugget to the query?

Content: TRUS-PB Infection Prophylaxis: Targeted vs. Empiric Antibiotics
Assessment: How consistent/coherent is the cluster?

Content: Seven studies, comprising 2735 patients (1371 in the TPA group and 1364 in the empiric prophylactic antibiotic group), reported the incidence of sepsis after TRUS-PB. Sepsis occurred in 18 patients (1.3%) in the TPA group compared with 24 (1.8%) in the empiric prophylactic antibiotic group, with no statistically significant difference between the two groups (RR: 0.74, 95% CI: 0.31-1.75, p = 0.5). (Confidence: 80.0%)

Content: This first systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials (RCTs) investigated the efficacy of rectal swab-based Targeted Antibiotic Prophylaxis (TPAs) prior to TRUS-PB in reducing infectious complications (fUTI and sepsis) compared to empirical antibiotic prophylaxis, noting that the overall effect of TPAs remains unclear due to small sample sizes and heterogeneous definitions of fUTI and sepsis across the individual RCTs. Content: Rectal Cleansing Tops Biopsy Infection Prevention Rankings
Assessment: How consistent/coherent is the cluster?

Content: An NMA indicated that the rectal cleansing group experienced the lowest sepsis rate. Based on rankogram and SUCRA values, rectal cleansing followed by transrectal biopsy was rank 1 (p = 0.917), while rectal culture-guided prophylactic antibiotics followed by transrectal biopsy was rank 2 (p score = 0.496). (Confidence: 100.0%)
Assessment: How relevant ist the nugget to the query?

Content: An analysis of 28 RCTs involving 10,179 participants revealed that rectal cleansing had the highest rankogram score (p score = 0.917) for reducing infectious complications such as sepsis (odds ratio 0.40, 95% confidence interval [0.28-0.58]), also leading to a lower incidence of UTIs and read-missions, and was followed by transperineal biopsy (p score = 0.496). (Confidence: 100.0%)
Assessment: How relevant ist the nugget to the query?

Content: Urological Prophylaxis: Balancing Stewardship, Resistance, and Asepsis
Assessment: How consistent/coherent is the cluster?

Content: Augmented prophylaxis using two or more different antibiotic classes contravenes antibiotic stewardship principles; instead, urological surgeons should prioritize and vigilantly maintain an aseptic environment to minimize infection risks from both endogenous (patient microbiome) and exogenous (nosocomial/health care-associated) sources. (Confidence: 80.0%)
Assessment: How relevant ist the nugget to the query?

Content: Both augmented and targeted prophylactic methods have been proven effective, though targeted prophylaxis requires a nonquinolone alternative antibiotic. Augmented prophylaxis has a potential negative ecological impact and is contrary to antibiotic stewardship principles; additionally, a growing number of UTIs is probably associated with increased antibiotic resistance. (Confidence: 100.0%)
Assessment: How relevant ist the nugget to the query?

Content: Povidone-Iodine Rectal Cleaning Prevents Biopsy Infections
Assessment: How consistent/coherent is the cluster?

Content: Transrectal cleaning with povidone-iodine is a measure to reduce infection during transrectal biopsy, according to a meta-analysis of 11 studies involving 2,237 patients that reported a Relative Risk (RR) of 0.47 (95% CI 0.36-0.61). (Confidence: 80.0%)

Content: During transrectal biopsy, infectious complications were less common when standard antibiotic prophylaxis was combined with povidone-iodine rectal cleaning compared to antibiotic prophylaxis alone. Current urology guidelines therefore recommend iodine rectal cleaning with povidone-iodine in addition to antibiotic prophylaxis before biopsy if the rate of local infectious complications is high. (Confidence: 80.0%)

Content: Transrectal Biopsy: Antibiotic Efficacy and Resistance
Assessment: How consistent/coherent is the cluster?

Content: A meta-analysis of 11 included studies with 1,753 patients demonstrated a significant reduction in infections following transrectal biopsy with antibiotic prophylaxis (RR 0.56, 95% CI 0.40-0.77) [169]. (Confidence: 80.0%)
Assessment: How relevant ist the nugget to the query?

Content: Transrectal (TR) procedures, which involve the rectal mucosa, have a higher infection rate of up to 5-7% and historically required comprehensive antibiotic prophylaxis. However, across multiple studies, there is a clear trend to minimize antibiotic use to reduce antibiotic resistance, aligning clinical practices with economic and public health benefits. Content: Transperineal Biopsy: Reducing Infections and Antibiotic Dependence
Assessment: How consistent/coherent is the cluster?

Content: Several reports demonstrated that rectal culture-directed antimicrobial prophylaxis can be an effective, reasonable approach to reduce post-biopsy infectious complications. (Confidence: 80.0%)

Content: Transperineal biopsy (TPB) is strongly favored over transrectal biopsy (TRB) due to its lower infection risk; studies indicate TPB nearly eliminated post-biopsy sepsis or was comparable to TRB with augmented antibiotic prophylaxis even without periprocedural antibiotics. Conversely, targeted antimicrobials for TRB based on rectal swab culture failed to reduce sepsis risk compared to empirical prophylaxis, which TRB widely requires but still results in ~5% infectious complications, highlighting that antibiotic administration significantly influences bacterial resistance, associated with millions of global deaths. (Confidence: 100.0%)

Content: Povidone-Iodine and Antibiotic Strategies Reduce Prostate Biopsy Infections
Assessment: How consistent/coherent is the cluster?

Content: Rectal disinfection with povidone-iodine immediately before transrectal prostate biopsy is recommended regardless of antibiotic choice, for which there is currently no gold standard in Germany. This non-antibiotic measure was associated with a significant reduction in post-interventional infections (RR 0.50, 95% CI: 0.38-0.65) in a meta-analysis of nine studies [Pradere 2021], and gains further importance in an era of increasing intestinal bacterial resistance. (Confidence: 100.0%)

Content: A previous meta-analysis [6] showed that combining prophylactic antibiotics with povidone-iodine rectal preparation before TRUS-PB significantly reduces the incidence of febrile urinary tract infection (fUTI) compared to empiric prophylactic antibiotic monotherapy (RR: 0.47, 95% CI: 0.3-0.75, p = 0.001). Content: Rectal Cleansing Significantly Reduces Post-Procedural Sepsis
Assessment: How consistent/coherent is the cluster?

Content: Rectal cleansing (Arm 1) significantly reduced the sepsis event rate from 0.18% (33/1823) to 0.05% (10/1830), with an absolute risk reduction (ARR) of 0.13% (NNT 769, OR 0.31, p=0.0011), whereas rectal culture-based prophylaxis (Arm 3) reduced rates from 0.15% (23/1473) to 0.08% (12/1430) with an ARR of 0.07% (NNT 1429), though this reduction was not statistically significant (OR 0.56, p=0.0855). (Confidence: 100.0%)

Content: Overall, rectal cleansing seemed to be the most effective strategy to prevent post-procedural sepsis, followed by rectal culture-based antibiotic prophylaxis and transperineal biopsy. (Confidence: 100.0%)

Content: Biopsy Infection Risks: TR vs. TP Approaches
Assessment: How consistent/coherent is the cluster?

Content: Post-biopsy sepsis is a rare complication, with one reported case among 1545 patients (TR: 1/762, TP: 0/783) including one grade 3 sepsis in the TR group in the PERFECT trial. The PREVENT trial indicated that transperineal biopsies without preventative antibiotics achieved similarly low infectious complications as transrectal biopsies using targeted antibiotic prophylaxis (recent update: 0/372 TP cases vs. 6/370 TR cases, difference -1%, p=0.01), with TR infections (1.6%) characterized as febrile but nonsevere. (Confidence: 100.0%)

Content: Low Complications, No Significant Differences
